title: How to Buy a Serger

steps.headline: Get a 2/3/4-thread serger for basic seamwork.
steps.description: Unlike a regular sewing machine, a serger makes stitches using multiple threads at the same time. Typically, the number of threads that a serger can handle ranges from 2 to 5. If you only use your serger occasionally or just need to do basic overlock stitches, a 2/3/4-thread serger (which can use between 2 and 4 threads at once) is probably sufficient. Some sergers don’t have a 2-thread setting, and can only do 3 or 4-thread stitches.

steps.headline: Choose a 5-thread serger for more advanced stitches.
steps.description: If you’re an advanced user and want to do more elaborate stitching, a 5-thread serger may be the best choice for you. 5-thread stitches are also ideal if you’ll be working with woven, knit, or heavyweight fabrics.Tip: Different types of serger stitches have different uses. Get a book on serger techniques or search for tutorials online to figure out the best type of stitch for your project. There are also sergers available on the market that can handle up to 10 threads at once!

steps.headline: Buy a serger with an automatic threader if you have limited dexterity.
steps.description: If you have limited manual dexterity or poor eyesight, threading a serger can be a struggle. Luckily, many serger models have an auto-thread feature that makes threading much easier. Self-threading sergers are generally more expensive than sergers that require manual threading, and relatively few companies make auto-threading models. If you need this feature, double-check the specifications of the serger you are interested in to make sure auto-threading is included.

steps.headline: Purchase a serger that also coverstitches to save money and space.
steps.description: Coverstitching is a kind of hem stitch that resembles a serger stitch. You can buy separate coverstitching and serging machines or buy one machine that does both if you have limited space or are on a budget. Switching between the serging and coverstitching features on a combined machine can be a hassle, so you may wish to get separate machines if you have the space. Unlike a serger, a coverstitching machine can’t trim extra fabric from the seam.

steps.headline: Opt for a higher-end serger if you plan to use the machine frequently.
steps.description: If you make garments for a living or if you’re studying fashion design, it’s a good idea to invest in a serger with as many features as possible. A more high-end machine is also a good option if you’ll be working with heavy-duty fabrics, like denim.

steps.headline: Pick a trusted brand.
steps.description: With so many different machines on the market, it can be hard to know where to start. Buying a well-established brand can help ensure that you’ll get a good-quality product. A few popular serger brands include Brother, Singer, Janome, Juki, and Babylock. If you already have a sewing machine in a brand you like and trust, consider getting a serger of the same brand.

steps.headline: Get a serger with metal parts.
steps.description: Metal machinery tends to hold up a lot better than plastic. When choosing a serger, try to find out what it’s made of—especially the interior parts. If possible, get a model that’s primarily made of metal parts. As a rule of thumb, choose a relatively heavy model. A lot of weight tends to mean that the machine is constructed solidly. Lighter models are more convenient if you need a portable serger, however.

steps.headline: Read reviews of the sergers you’re interested in.
steps.description: Before you settle on a serger, do some research online. User reviews can give you a lot of information that you might not get from the official product specifications. Look for information about the serger’s features, functionality, durability, and customer support options.Tip: Find out if the serger you’re interested in comes with an instructional DVD or online instructional video. Audio-visual aids can be very helpful when you’re trying to figure out how to use a complex machine like a serger. Pay particular attention to what reviewers say about the instruction manual. If the instructions aren’t easy to understand, then you’re probably in for a lot of frustration.

steps.headline: Try the serger before you buy it if possible.
steps.description: The best way to know if a serger is right for you is to test it out. If possible, try multiple machines before you pick one. This will give you an idea of how the machine feels, how easy it is to use, and how well it handles the kinds of stitches you’ll be using it for. Try bringing your own fabric to the store or dealership so that you can experiment with different stitches.

steps.headline: Base your selection on the features, not the price.
steps.description: A hefty price tag doesn’t necessarily mean you’re getting the best possible serger for your needs. On the other hand, you don’t want to go for the cheapest possible serger and end up with a lemon that doesn’t even have the features you want! Try to find a serger that both fits your budget and has all the features you’re looking for. If you have an idea of the features you need, try a variety of high- and low-end sergers that meet your specifications. You may actually find that the one you like best is relatively affordable! The prices of sergers usually have more to do with the materials and manufacturing processes used to produce them than the actual features and capabilities of the serger.

steps.headline: Look for a serger that works with lots of accessories.
steps.description: If you do a lot of specialized sewing and want to get the most out of your serger, you may end up wanting to add some extra bells and whistles to your machine. Try to find a serger that is compatible with a wide range of accessories, such as special presser feet that allow you to do specific stitches. Even if you don’t need any special accessories when you’re first learning to use your serger, it’s good to have that option available as you start to master new techniques.

steps.headline: Buy your serger straight from the dealership if you can.
steps.description: Buying online or from a big-box store may be convenient, but you won’t really have an idea of what you’re getting until you get your machine home. Instead, try to buy your serger directly from a small dealer. That way, you’ll have a chance to test out the machine and talk to a specialist who can explain its features to you in detail. Some sewing machine dealerships also offer classes and cleaning and repair services.
